Major or Mild Vascular Neurocognitive Disorder
A. The criteria are met for major or mild neurocognitive disorder.
B. The clinical features are consistent with a vascular etiology, as
suggested by either of the following:
1. Onset of the cognitive deficits is temporally related to one or
more cerebrovascular events.
2. Evidence for decline is prominent in complex attention (in-
cluding processing speed) and frontal-executive function.
C. There is evidence of the presence of cerebrovascular disease
from history, physical examination, and/or neuroimaging consid-
ered sufficient to account for the neurocognitive deficits.
D. The symptoms are not better explained by another brain disease
or systemic disorder.
